b'and\xe2\x80\xa6\n\nAlong the equator, sitting exactly between two hemispheres that always trend in opposite ways, the duration of sunlight & darkness remains unchanged throughout the year.  There are no astronomical seasons, and their twilight is always the shortest -- less than 30 mins.'

b'June 21, 2022
Welcome to the Solstice.  On this day...

1. the North Pole tips directly to the Sun - 23.5 degrees

2. the entire Arctic circle never sees sunset

3. the entire Antarctic circle never sees daylight

b'Lunar eclipses occur on average every two or three years and are visible to all the billions of people who can see the Moon when it happens. \n \nSo, contrary to what you may have been told, lunar eclipses are not rare.'
b'Lunar eclipses are so un-spectacular that if nobody told you what was happening to the Moon you\xe2\x80\x99d probably not notice at all.\n\nJust sayin\xe2\x80\x99.'
b'Unlike solar eclipses, which are location-dependent, everyone on the side of Earth facing the full Moon (i.e. the Sun has set for you) can witness a lunar eclipse.'

b'Decades ago, when there was more air pollution, sunsets were often beet-red. That color would refract into Earth\xe2\x80\x99s shadow in space tinting the fully eclipsed Moon. \n\nHaven\xe2\x80\x99t seen that effect in years. The Moon more commonly goes dark, leaving nothing \xe2\x80\x9cbloody\xe2\x80\x9d about the Blood Moon'

b'Dear Earthlings currently in darkness:\n\nRight about now, the full Moon is passing into Earth\xe2\x80\x99s conical shadow in space. The event is long and boring, lasting 3.5 hours.  For the middle 84 minutes, the Moon is all but fully darkened as it enters the deepest part of Earth\xe2\x80\x99s shadow.'

b'@GuestSt18702890 @NASA @elonmusk @SpaceForceCSO @SpaceForceDoD @ScienceNews Lunar phases are just the Sun illuminaing the Moon in different amounts during the Moon\xe2\x80\x99s moonthly orbit around Earth.  Has nothing to do with Earth\xe2\x80\x99s shadow. Occasionally, the Moon\xe2\x80\x99s path enters Earth\xe2\x80\x99s shadow. That can happen only during Full Moon.  Behold, a Lunar eclipse.'

b'By the 1920s the mysterious, Green-emitting space element "nebulium was ID\'ed as oxygen, but behaving oddly in the rarefied conditions of space.'
b'Mid-19th century, a mysterious element was discovered in space nebulae. It emits deep Green, and was dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cnebulium." https://t.co/sVPHe1sQez'
b'Rarefied gas just might be Irish: The element oxygen, in Aurora and in the near-vacuum conditions of space, radiates pure Green. https://t.co/Pc8zXMy4JH'
b'Stars are not Irish: The laws of radiative physics conspire in such a way that there are no Green stars in the Universe. They come in three basic colors: Reddish, White, & Blueish.'

b'We think of US paper money as                                                                                                            being Green. But face-side ink is primarily black. So instead of "Greenbacks" it could legitimately be called "Blackfronts" https://t.co/7XUqODregB'
b"Curiously, light-loving Green plants reject the Sun's Green light, reflecting it back at you, which is why they look Green. https://t.co/7iUrQHTRno"
b'The "Green\xe2\x80\x9d movement might be misnamed. Experiments show that increased CO2 promotes photosynthesis, making plants grow faster.'

b'Solar flux scales as the square of the distance.

If you do the math, Earth today receives about 6% more solar energy than in July.

But we\xe2\x80\x99re also moving faster in our orbit. Which largely cancels out the net gain.

That\xe2\x80\x99s why Winter is only 89 days long. Summer: 94 days https://t.co/ha4oBScC4j'

b'Merry Perihelion to planet Earth.

147,105,050 kilometers from the Sun

In our annual oval orbit, today we are closer to the Sun than at any other time of the year.

But not by much -- about 3% closer than at Aphelion, our farthest distance from the Sun six months from now. https://t.co/rEyoT622uA'

b'Santa doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know Zoology:

b'How does weight change if Earth stops turning?

Santa on the North Pole weighs the same as ever. Everyone else loses the centrifugal force, which peaks at the Equator.

There, a 150 pound person weighs 1/2 pound more.'
b'Santa is pale because he\xe2\x80\x99s in the middle of six months of darkness on Earth\xe2\x80\x99s North Pole. And he delivers gifts only at night.'

b'Since the Northern Arctic is just ocean, Santa\xe2\x80\x99s North Pole workshop has only ever existed on a floating sheet of ice.\n\nImages that portray Santa\xe2\x80\x99s workshop with pine trees and snow-capped hills on the horizon are geographically underinfomred. https://t.co/zyGpAPfMAt'

b'Santa surely keeps track of how many hours pass & how long the Elf union allows them to work, but on the North Pole, where all Time-Zones meet, the actual time of day has no meaning. https://t.co/d1LsJhQBfr'
b'Random Santa Fact:\n\nLongitude lines are the boundaries of Time Zones. So at the North Pole, where all lines of longitude meet, clock-time has no meaning.'

b"Last round of Gift Suggestions\xe2\x80\xa6

b'Space Aliens might be surprised to learn that a third of our lives \xe2\x80\x94  a third of every Earth rotation \xe2\x80\x94 we lay semi-comatose on cushions.'
b'Would be cool if space aliens landed on Earth and instead demanded,\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake me to your common people!"'
b'If I were ever abducted by Space Aliens, the first thing I\xe2\x80\x99d ask is whether they came from a planet where fellow Aliens also deny science.'

b"This is what happens when Space Aliens discover you're eavesdropping on them.

Or instead, maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s what happens when a country regresses in its urge to lead the world in Science.

b'Note to HOLLYWOOD:\n\nA Space Alien with no DNA in common with life on Earth should look more different from life on Earth than **any** two life forms on Earth look from each other.'

b'Sun tables for today show slightly more than 12 hours of daylight.\n\nLight bends on entering Earth\xe2\x80\x99s atmosphere from space. The sunrise or sunset you see is the lagged location of the Sun\xe2\x80\x99s refracted light, and not the the Sun itself, adding unearned minutes of daylight \xe2\x80\x94 daily. https://t.co/iUv19Jn6OB'

b"@TheWhiskyMaker @symbolium @RichardCheese Caused by the refraction of sunlight entering Earth\xe2\x80\x99s atmosphere from space.  Also, sunrise times reference a different spot on the Sun than sunset times.\n\nCombined, they add multiple minutes of daylight that wouldn't otherwise be there."

b'Astrologically, today is the \xe2\x80\x9cFirst Point of Aries,\xe2\x80\x9d when the Sun first visits the constellation Aries on the sky. b'How often does a Blue Moon land on Halloween, you may ask?\n\nDepends. It could be November 1 for you, while time zones to your West are still trick-or-treating. Back in the 20th and 21st centuries, the USA saw eight Halloween Blue Moons: 1906 1925 1944 2020 2039 2058 2077 & 2096. https://t.co/KxYQeQLY6w'

b"The expression \xe2\x80\x9cOnce in a Blue Moon\xe2\x80\x9d is colloquial for \xe2\x80\x9cThe thing hardly ever happens.\xe2\x80\x9d  But If you meant it literally, then that thing will occur every two or three years.\n\nSo, like most cosmic happenings, Blue Moons aren't entirely rare, even if we want to think they are."

b'Blue Moon alert:

This year, a Full Moon lands on Halloween. With a 29.5-day cycle of phases, any time you squeeze two full moons into a month, the second one is called the \xe2\x80\x9cBlue Moon.\xe2\x80\x9d

Yes, that means February is S.O.L. in its bid for Blue Moons. https://t.co/6u7g95ZCH1'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n\nA third of you (still) want Pluto to be a planet.  But it\xe2\x80\x99s not. So get over it.'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n\nNearly (only?) 400 out of 185,000 respondents have been hospitalized for COVID-19. Of course we don\xe2\x80\x99t know how many have died. But for all others, please continue to stay smart, stay healthy, and heed the advice medial professionals'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n\n7% of you are Vegan/Vegetarian, which is close to the 8% of you in the world\xe2\x80\x99s population.  Meanwhile, nearly 90% are omnivores, I among you. Although lately I consume dead animals no more than about two days a week.'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n\nMore than 80% of you are non-religious. But one in 14 (7%) identify as having religion as a way of life. You follow me knowing that not all of my content resonates with your views. Thank you for coming along for the ride.'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n\nOne fourth of you identify as politically Centrist with more than half identifying as Liberal.  So the Conservative voices that arise in my threads, though ardent, are a small minority of all followers.'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n\nOne in four of you have visited only one, or no other countries in your life. In my experience, it\xe2\x80\x99s always good to do all you can to see how others live \xe2\x80\x94 lest you think your way of life is the only way of life.'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n\n43% of you know only one Language. I am among you, but only if you don\xe2\x80\x99t count the computer languages I know.  And congrats to the  7% who know four or more languages. That\xe2\x80\x99s badass in every way.'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n\nDomestically & especially Internationally, more Men use Twitter than Women. Maybe Twitter breeds over-talkers, best suiting male modes of interaction. In any case, my followers are 78% Male 20% Female.  With 1% Non-binary.'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n \n67% of my followers self-identify as having \xe2\x80\x9cLight\xe2\x80\x9d skin, and 1% with \xe2\x80\x9cDark\xe2\x80\x9d skin, which simply tells me I am badly under-represented in Africa.'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n\nSixty percent of you are fluent in the Metric System. Wow.  Either Americans are successfully inching in that direction, or most of my following is International.'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n\nConsistent with all users of Twitter, there\xe2\x80\x99s a nearly equal split between City living and the Suburbs, with one in seven of you living in Rural zones - where night skies are filled with stars.'
b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:\n\nAs expected, 90% of my followers live in the northern hemisphere \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x98cause that\xe2\x80\x99s where most of the land is.'

b'Reflections on the statistics of my followers:

Most of you are half my age or less. More significantly, only 3.5% of my followers are my age or older. That\xe2\x80\x99s half of who in that age group uses Twitter.

I wish I knew what any of that means.'

b'If you must know:  The word parsec is a contraction of \xe2\x80\x9cparallax-second\xe2\x80\x9d, the distance a star would be from the Sun if one half of its parallax angle subtended one second of arc.'

b'Ignoring the Kessel Run abomination in Star Wars, a Parsec is an obscure unit of distance in classical astronomy equal to 3.26 light years. A megaparsec is a million of these. b'Credit to Pope Gregory\xe2\x80\x99s Jesuit priests for figuring out the Julian calendar needed updating - before telescopes, and while Christendom was sure the Sun orbited Earth. \n\nFifty years later, Jesuits would prosecute Galileo for saying (and flaunting) that Earth orbits the Sun. https://t.co/2bX20b0wP4'

b'By 1582, the Julian calendar, with a Leap Day every four years, had accumulated TEN extra days relative to Earth\xe2\x80\x99s orbit.  So Pope Gregory jump-started his new and exquisitely accurate calendar by canceling 10 days that year, in which October 4 was followed by October 15.'

b'The 1582 Gregorian update to the Julian Calendar prescribes: The century years 1600 1700 1800 1900 & 2000 are all divisible by four, but 1700 1800 1900 were not leap years, yet 1600 & 2000 were. And 2400 will be.\n\nOn February 29, 2000 most had no idea how rare that Leap Day was.'

b'The Leap Day alone overcorrects the calendar, requiring we remove a Leap Day every century year.

But that under-corrects the calendar, requiring we put a Leap Day back in, every four centuries. 

Behold the Gregorian Calendar.'
b'@BlueIsRue @Snow_Miser_ The week is what\xe2\x80\x99s arbitrary. Months come from \xe2\x80\x9cmoonths\xe2\x80\x9d.  A bad approximation of the lunar cycle.'
b'Happy Birthday to the less than 0.07% of the human population born on a Leap Day. https://t.co/hMOtfODqKp'

b'The film "Ad Astra" showed an excellent lunar landscape. Desolate. Without color. Bright in sunlight. Dark in shadows. Daytime starry skies. b'The film "Ad Astra" loves showing weightless astronauts. But space is not inherently weightless. If your engines fire constantly because you\'re in a hurry to get to the Moon or to Mars, then the acceleration creates artificial gravity \xe2\x80\x94 at the rear-end of the ship. Always.'

b'The film "Ad Astra" has Moon Pirates. Moon Pirates? What are they thinking? Buried treasures on the Moon?  If the Pirates knew how expensive it is to be a Pirate in space, they might have just stayed on Earth and become investment bankers. https://t.co/uFRULeSocy'

b'In the film "Ad Astra", they announce the Moon is almost full, yet a "blue marble" gibbous Earth hangs in the sky \xe2\x80\x94 a geometric impossibility. b'Not that anybody asked, but\xe2\x80\xa6
 
Measure the circumference of your head in inches, then divide that number by Pi. That\xe2\x80\x99s your Hat size.

Mathematically, your Hat size is the diameter of your head in inches if your head were a perfect sphere.'

b"So that we're all on the same Pi-page\xe2\x80\xa6\n\nIf you measure the Circumference of a circle and divide it by the Diameter of the same circle, you get the value of Pi.  And that value of Pi is the same for ANY size circle you draw."

b'#IKnewIWasOld when the Obituary Pages became a fascinating read.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when Adult fans come up to me and say \xe2\x80\x9cI watched you on PBS when I was a kid.\xe2\x80\x9d'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when I decided to to drink bottles of Wine that cost twice as much, but do so only half as often.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when it became unsafe to ignite the appropriate number of Candles on my Birthday Cake.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when I stopped liking Barbecue Potato Chips'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when I started liking all the Music my parents listened to.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when I saw the next generation complain about social issues that my generation didn\xe2\x80\x99t yet have the awareness to notice.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when the urge to go exercise was easily overrun by the competing urge to take a nap.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when at Restaurants, I started ordering appetizers for my main course.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when I could no longer do a full split on a dance floor, but also no longer cared that I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when I started caring more about what is objectively true than about hurting people\xe2\x80\x99s feelings.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when my family started buying number-candles to represent my age on a Cake rather than single candles themselves.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld the day my growing son was simultaneously bigger than I wanted to lift, and bigger than I was able lift.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when I could swallow a shot of Whisky without wincing.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when I would walk past a Candy Store and not even notice I was walking past a Candy Store.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when the threat of being sent to bed early sounded like a reward rather than a punishment.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when I started liking Blue-Cheese'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when I had no interest in accelerating faster than the guy next to me out of the traffic light that just turned green.'
b'#IKnewIWasOld when on my 60th birthday, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel a day over 60.'

b'#WhenIWasYourAge it was people who were smart, and phones that were dumb.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge James Bond was probably infected with multiple STDs.'
b'#WhenMyParentsWereYourAge \xe2\x80\x9cIn God We Trust" was neither on our money, the Pledge of Allegiance, or the front wall of Congress'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge The weather started feeling cold in September.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge My car got seven miles per gallon. Ten, downhill. Twelve, with a tailwind.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge, Before scooper laws, nobody knew for sure what squeezing Dog Poop into the palm of your hand felt like.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge You could kiss your loved-one goodbye at the airport gate. And return home.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge People dressed up when they flew on Airplanes.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge A commercial airplane, the Concorde, cruised at twice the speed of sound \xe2\x80\x94 3x faster than planes today.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge America had the tallest buildings in the world.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge America launched its own Astronauts into space \xe2\x80\x94 with its own Spaceships.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge We cured diseases and went to the Moon, benchmarking our usage of the word \xe2\x80\x9cAwesome."'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge Rain Forests were called Jungles. And Wetlands were called Swamps.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge Sauce was called Gravy.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge Partly sunny days were called partly cloudy.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge All hotel rooms smelled of cigarette smoke.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge Second-hand smoke was when somebody offered you a toke on whatever they were puffing.'
b"#WhenIWasYourAge An ashtray was a time-honored gift you could bring to a person's home."
b'#WhenIWasYourAge Extracting ketchup from its narrow-necked glass bottle occasionally made you question the laws of gravity.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge We had candy cigarettes, gun-shaped cigarette lighters, and sucked flavored sugar through a straw.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge Corn Pops Frosted Flakes & Honey Smacks were instead called Sugar Pops Sugar Frosted Flakes & Sugar Smacks'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge We consumed Twinkles, Cool Whip, and Yoo-hoo, without questioning their chemical composition.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge Milk was not yet the farthest thing from the front entrance to your grocery store.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge A photograph lived inside your camera, cloaked in mystery for weeks, until you took exactly 35 more photos.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge Photographs were records of your life experience, and not the life experience itself.'
b'#WhenIWasYourAge Pluto was a planet. T-Rex dragged his tail. And the Brontosaurus was always chewing vegetation.'
b'A rant on #WhenIWasYourAge follows\xe2\x80\xa6'
